intent: Organizational security culture, human factors, governance mindset, and behavioral risk reduction principles.
coreThesis: Security failures are often behavioral and systemic, not purely technical. Culture determines resilience.

principles.name: Security Is a Shared Responsibility
principles.summary: Security is not only an IT function; it requires participation across leadership, engineering, operations, and staff.

principles.name: Psychological Safety in Reporting
principles.summary: Employees must feel safe reporting mistakes or suspicious events without fear of punishment.
principles.impact: Improves early detection and reduces concealment of incidents.

principles.name: Continuous Training & Awareness
principles.summary: Security awareness is an ongoing behavioral reinforcement process.
methods: Contextual training tied to real workflows.

principles.name: Executive Buy-In & Tone from the Top

humanRiskPatterns.description: Manipulation of human trust to bypass technical controls.
Unauthorized use of tools or services outside governance oversight.
humanRiskPatterns.impact: Unmonitored data exposure and compliance gaps.

humanRiskPatterns.description: Gradual acceptance of insecure shortcuts due to productivity pressure.

organizationalControls.name: Clear Policy Framework
organizationalControls.description: Policies must be understandable, enforceable, and aligned with daily operations.

organizationalControls.name: Defined Incident Playbooks
organizationalControls.description: Employees should know exactly what to do if they suspect compromise.

organizationalControls.name: Security Metrics & Reporting
organizationalControls.description: Track phishing rates, patch timelines, incident detection speed, and awareness engagement.
